translated: The Exclamations
With Dabba the Mallian (The Second)
Thus have I heard.

original: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṁ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
analyzed: ekam samayam bhagavā sāvatthiyam viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme
translated: On one occasion the Blessed One was dwelling at Savatthi in Jeta’s Grove, Anathapindika’s Park.
There the Blessed One addressed the bhikkhus thus:
“Bhikkhus!”
“Venerable sir!” those bhikkhus replied.
The Blessed One said this:

original: “Dabbassa, bhikkhave, mallaputtassa vehāsaṁ abbhuggantvā ākāse antalikkhe pallaṅkena
analyzed: dabbassa bhikkhave malla puttassa vehāsam abbhuggantvā ākāse antalikkhe pallaṅkena
translated: “Bhikkhus, when Dabba the Mallian rose into the air at the Bhesakalaka shrine, sat down cross-legged in the air,

original: nisīditvā tejodhātuṁ samāpajjitvā vuṭṭhahitvā parinibbutassa sarīrassa jhāyamānassa
analyzed: nisīditvā tejodhātum samāpajjitvā vuṭṭhahitvā parinibbutassa sarīrassa jhāyamānassa
translated: in space, entered the fire-element attainment, emerged therefrom, and attained final Nibbana,

original: ḍayhamānassa neva chārikā paññāyittha na masi.
analyzed: ḍayhamānassa na iva chārikā paññāyittha na masi
translated: his body burning and being consumed, there was no ash and no soot to be seen.

original: Seyyathāpi nāma sappissa vā telassa vā jhāyamānassa ḍayhamānassa neva chārikā paññāyati na masi;
analyzed: seyyathā api nāma sappissa vā telassa vā jhāyamānassa ḍayhamānassa na iva chārikā paññāyati na masi
translated: Just as when ghee or oil is burning and being consumed, there is no ash and no soot to be seen,

original: evamevaṁ kho, bhikkhave, dabbassa mallaputtassa vehāsaṁ abbhuggantvā ākāse antalikkhe
analyzed: evam evam kho bhikkhave dabbassa malla puttassa vehāsam abbhuggantvā ākāse antalikkhe
translated: so too, when Dabba the Mallian rose into the air at the Bhesakalaka shrine, sat down cross-legged in the air,🔽in space,

original: pallaṅkena nisīditvā tejodhātuṁ samāpajjitvā vuṭṭhahitvā parinibbutassa sarīrassa
analyzed: pallaṅkena nisīditvā tejodhātum samāpajjitvā vuṭṭhahitvā parinibbutassa sarīrassa
translated: after entering the fire element, after emerging, after attaining final extinguishment,

original: jhāyamānassa ḍayhamānassa neva chārikā paññāyittha na masī”ti.
analyzed: jhāyamānassa ḍayhamānassa na iva chārikā paññāyittha na masi iti
translated: after the body was burning and being burned, neither ashes nor soot were to be found.”

original: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṁ viditvā tāyaṁ velāyaṁ imaṁ udānaṁ udānesi:
analyzed: atha kho bhagavā etam attham viditvā tāyam velāyam imam udānam udānesi
translated: Then the Blessed One, having known the significance of that, on that occasion exclaimed:

analyzed: ayaḥ ghana hataḥ sa iva  jalataḥ jātavedaso
translated: “Just as when an iron ball,🔽red-hot, is thrown into water,
it splutters and sputters
and its movement is not discerned.
So it is with those rightly released,
who have crossed over the flood of sensuality,
their going is not discerned,
having attained the unshakable bliss.”
The tenth.🔽The eighth sub-chapter on Pāṭaligāma is finished.
The summary:
Four on extinguishment were spoken,
Cunda, Pāṭaligāma,
The crossroads, and Visākhā,
with Dabba, those are the ten.
The summary of the sub-chapters in the Udāna

analyzed: vaggam idam paṭhamam vara bodhi  vaggam idam dutiyam mucalindo
translated: This is the first sub-chapter, the excellent awakening,🔽this is the second sub-chapter, the Nāga Mucalinda,
the third is the excellent sub-chapter on Nanda,
and the fourth is the excellent sub-chapter on Meghiya.
The fifth excellent sub-chapter here is on Soṇa,

analyzed: chaṭṭhama vagga vara nti ja c ca andhaḥ
translated: The best of the sixth chapter is the Blind Man;
The best of the seventh chapter is the Small One,
The eighth chapter is the One Going to Pāṭaliputta.

analyzed: asīti manūnaka sutta vara  vaggam idaṭṭhakam su vibhatta
translated: The best of the discourses with more than eighty,🔽This chapter is well-analyzed,
Taught by the Visionary Vimal,

analyzed: addhā hi tam udānam iti idam āhu
translated: Surely they call this an exclamation.
The Udana Collection is finished.
